metadata.title: A multi-disciplinary framework for cyber attribution
rq_lines: 0: What types of evidence are used?
1: What methods are used?
2: How are frameworks and models operationalized for cyber attribution?

section_open_coding.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: A major factor in this situation is that attribution within the cyber domain continues to be almost impossible, with criminals, terrorists and hackers able to carry out activity with relative impunity.
evidence.paraphrase: The authors state that cyber attribution remains essentially unattainable, enabling attackers to operate with relative impunity.
evidence.researcher_comment: This sentence frames the core problem motivating the work: lack of reliable attribution. It is a high-level claim (no quantitative support here) and justifies multidisciplinary solutions. Be cautious: it's a general statement rather than an empirical finding.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: The ultimate goal of the project is to create a framework suitable for the sharing of attribution data between technical specialists.
evidence.paraphrase: The project aims to develop a framework to enable technical specialists to share attribution data.
evidence.researcher_comment: This specifies the central objective of the thesis and directly answers what solution is proposed. It is a normative project goal rather than an evaluated result.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: - The framework must be mathematically based in order to enable validation of the techniques used
evidence.paraphrase: A design requirement is that the framework be mathematically founded to permit validation of techniques.
evidence.researcher_comment: This requirement sets an operational constraint (reproducibility/validation) that shapes subsequent design decisions (confidence scores, attribute aggregation). It is prescriptive but lacks formal specification here.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: Each attribute will be in the form of a tuple, as each attribute will have an associated confidence value.
evidence.paraphrase: Attributes are modelled as tuples that include an associated confidence value.
evidence.researcher_comment: This defines the data model for attributes, enabling numeric combination and comparison across libraries. Caveat: how confidence values are calibrated and aggregated matters for robustness and is only partially specified later.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: The confidence value itself can be represented by any numerical value, as long as all analysts agree on a standard prior to using the framework.
evidence.paraphrase: Confidence may use any numeric scale provided analysts agree on a common standard beforehand.
evidence.researcher_comment: This allows flexibility but requires inter-analyst calibration to be meaningful; absence of a mandatory standard introduces potential inconsistency across users and datasets.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: For the purposes of testing the framework the values 0-1 have been chosen, with 0.2 intervals, with 0 representing highly unlikely and 1 representing almost certain.
evidence.paraphrase: In experiments the framework uses a 0–1 confidence scale with 0.2 increments where 0=highly unlikely and 1=almost certain.
evidence.researcher_comment: Provides explicit calibration used in testing (coarse 0.2 steps). This is actionable but may reduce resolution for borderline evidence; the choice is pragmatic for demonstration.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: The defined classes are: - Text_String - True_False - Integer - Real_Numbers - IPv4
evidence.paraphrase: The framework defines attribute data types including Text_String, True_False, Integer, Real_Numbers and IPv4.
evidence.researcher_comment: A lightweight typing/taxonomy is provided to support type-specific comparison and validation. Note IPv6 is absent (author notes IPv6 as future work), limiting current network coverage.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: The IP address is the primary method of recognition in any cyber incident.
evidence.paraphrase: The authors identify the IP address as the primary identifier in cyber incidents.
evidence.researcher_comment: This justifies prioritization of an IPv4 library and explains operational emphasis; however IPs are easily spoofed or reflect stepping stones, so alone they are weak for attribution.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: Due to the majority of incident response and monitoring tools being based upon network traffic it is the IP address that is the most useful piece of data to be shared so that other monitoring tools can hone in on the potentially malicious traffic and the response teams can begin to block that traffic.
evidence.paraphrase: Because most IR/monitoring tools use network traffic, sharing IP addresses is the most useful immediate data to direct other monitoring and mitigation tools.
evidence.researcher_comment: Operational rationale for why IP-centric sharing is prioritized in fast-time investigations; depends on timeliness and whether IPs map to actors (false positives possible).
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: defines traceback attribution as ”any attribution technique that begins with the defending computer and recursively steps backwards in the attack path toward the attacker”
evidence.paraphrase: Traceback attribution is defined as techniques that start at the defender and step backwards along the attack path toward the attacker.
evidence.researcher_comment: This formal definition clarifies one attribution category (network-path based). Practical limitations (NATs, proxies, stepping stones) make reliable traceback difficult in many real-world cases.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: Full attribution is when a specific action can be assigned to an individual person.
evidence.paraphrase: Full attribution means assigning a particular action to a specific individual person.
evidence.researcher_comment: This establishes the highest evidentiary target (suitable for legal proceedings) and clarifies that 'full attribution' requires linking actor identity to an observed action rather than just a machine or group.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: An Actor, A, is an entity or person who is performing an action through cyber means.
evidence.paraphrase: The framework models an Actor (A) as an entity or person performing actions via cyber means.
evidence.researcher_comment: This is a simple formalisation anchoring the actor-centric model; useful for mapping attributes to actors, but the model assumes attributes can be associated with actors which may be contested in noisy environments.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: There is currently no formalised system to enable the sharing of attribution data between multiple disciplines.
evidence.paraphrase: The authors assert there is no standardized system for multi-disciplinary sharing of attribution data.
evidence.researcher_comment: This gap motivates the proposed framework; note the author acknowledges commercial/private solutions exist but not a formal open system—this claim merits external verification.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: A number of these technical solutions require a fundamental change to the way in which networking and the internet works.
evidence.paraphrase: Many proposed technical traceback/attribution solutions demand fundamental changes to internet architecture.
evidence.researcher_comment: This highlights scalability and deployment barriers for several academic proposals; it supports the pragmatic focus on deployable, incremental solutions. It also raises policy and governance obstacles.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: This first experiment resulted in a 100% success rate with all candidates successfully identifying the intelligence gap.
evidence.paraphrase: Experiment 1 reported that all participants (100%) correctly identified intelligence gaps using the framework.
evidence.researcher_comment: Strong usability signal for the gap-detection visualisation, but sample size and test design details are limited; results may not generalize beyond the experiment's participants and conditions.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: The tool was run over a sample of 18,000 (N) previously known malware samples.
evidence.paraphrase: The authors executed static analysis on a malware corpus of 18,000 samples to assess attribute prevalence.
evidence.researcher_comment: Large-sample static analysis increases empirical weight of findings; however static-only analysis misses dynamic indicators and may under-detect network artifacts.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: The results of the static analysis found that there are a number of attributes that meet the requirements. These were: - IP Address - Domain - Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA) - E-Mail - BitCoin Address - Date of Compilation - Dropped Files - Packer - Entropy - Strings
evidence.paraphrase: Static analysis identified repeatable malware attributes useful for attribution: IP, domain, DGA, email, bitcoin address, compilation date, dropped files, packer, entropy, and strings.
evidence.researcher_comment: This enumerated attribute set is empirically derived and can feed library development; several items (IP, domain, bitcoin) have strong linkage potential, others (strings, entropy) are noisy and require aggregation.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: The experiment verified the attributes selected from the original data set are the most prevalent for the use in attribution. The experiment however highlighted the requirement to not rely on an individual attribute in isolation, and it is the collection of attributes as a whole that create the fingerprint.
evidence.paraphrase: Experiments validated prevalent attribution attributes but emphasized that reliable fingerprints require combining multiple attributes rather than relying on any single indicator.
evidence.researcher_comment: This synthesis is a key empirical insight: multi-attribute fusion yields better linkage than single markers. Caveat: verification used known malware families (proxy for same author) rather than independently proven authorship.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: It was shown to be suitable for multidisciplinary work through the inclusion of linguistic and RF libraries.
evidence.paraphrase: The framework was demonstrated to support multidisciplinary attribution by incorporating linguistic and radio-frequency libraries.
evidence.researcher_comment: This supports extensibility claims and the core novelty (multidisciplinary data fusion). Testing scope was limited to selected libraries; broader interoperability remains to be proven.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence.quote: Proposed libraries would include, but are not limited to; - HTML - Scripting languages - Social Media - IPV6 - Bluetooth
evidence.paraphrase: Future work proposes additional libraries for HTML, scripting languages, social media, IPv6 and Bluetooth to broaden attribution coverage.
evidence.researcher_comment: Author outlines clear extension roadmap that targets important application and physical-layer sources; implementation and maintenance overheads are non-trivial and would affect scalability.
evidence.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence_harvesting.quote: For the purposes of cyber attribution, our focus is from that of cyber security.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The thesis limits the concept of 'cyber' for attribution work to a cyber-security perspective, i.e. attributes relevant to security analysts.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This statement narrows the project's scope to cyber‑security use cases, which clarifies which attributes will be prioritised. It excludes broader socio-technical interpretations of 'cyber' and will shape library/feature selection. Analysts should note this when mapping findings to other research questions outside security-focused attribution.

evidence_harvesting.quote: for the purpose of this thesis it was decided that cyber was information based.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The thesis defines 'cyber' as information‑based, i.e. focused on digital information (data and metadata) for attribution purposes.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: Explicitly framing 'cyber' as information-based steers attribute collection toward digital artefacts and metadata rather than non-digital context. This decision helps bound the framework but may omit non-digital signals that could be relevant in some attribution cases.

evidence_harvesting.quote: Although this phrase was originally used as a slang term for the internet its official dictionary definition is ”a realm of electronic communication”.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The document adopts the dictionary meaning of 'cyber space' as 'a realm of electronic communication', covering any medium that transmits or stores digital information.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: A purposely broad, medium‑agnostic definition that permits inclusion of RF, wired, and other channels in attribution libraries. The breadth aids extensibility but may increase heterogeneity of attributes to manage.

evidence_harvesting.quote: Cyber Security therefore relates to any action that is required to keep the information safe and available.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: Cyber security is defined as actions taken to keep information safe and available (i.e., preservation of CIA properties) for attribution and defence.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: Tying security to information availability/safety focuses attribution on evidence that affects confidentiality, integrity, and availability. The definition also explicitly allows physical attacks on equipment to be considered under 'cyber security'.

evidence_harvesting.quote: Ultimately it is the search for characteristics which can be associated with an attack or an individual.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The thesis frames cyber attribution as the identification of characteristics that can be associated with an attack or an individual actor.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This operational definition justifies building attribute libraries and a taxonomy of features. It is intentionally broad — 'characteristics' must be disambiguated into concrete, testable attributes (which the thesis attempts via libraries).

evidence_harvesting.quote: The ultimate goal of traceback attribution is to follow the communications back to the original source, usually in the form of an IP address.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: Traceback attribution aims to trace communications back to their origin, typically identified as an IP address.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This sets expectations for what traceback can provide but the thesis elsewhere notes practical obstacles (spoofing, proxies, non-cooperative networks). The definition is network-centric and may understate challenges in attributing persons rather than devices.

evidence_harvesting.quote: Full attribution is when a specific action can be assigned to an individual person.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: Full attribution is defined as assigning a specific cyber action to a named individual, the level required for legal proceedings.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This distinguishes levels of attribution and highlights that 'full attribution' carries much higher evidentiary burdens than device- or traceback-level attribution. It signals the need for rigorous evidentiary standards for legal use.

evidence_harvesting.quote: At the conclusion of the project there is a proposed framework for the use of analysts working on the attribution problem.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The project's principal output is a proposed analyst-oriented cyber attribution framework.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This is the central deliverable claimed by the thesis; subsequent text summarises validation experiments but further external validation and peer replication are needed to judge generalisability. The claim is descriptive of output rather than evaluative.

evidence_harvesting.quote: It was shown to be suitable for multidisciplinary work through the inclusion of linguistic and RF libraries.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The authors report the framework is suitable for multidisciplinary collaboration by incorporating linguistic and radio‑frequency libraries.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: Empirical support is limited to those two library domains; while encouraging, this result does not prove generalisability across other disciplines. Integration and semantic-mapping challenges between domains remain an implementation risk.

evidence_harvesting.quote: This was an especially pleasing demonstration of the framework as an information sharing platform as a colleague without any prior training was able to use the framework to extract the relevant information.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: In a live demonstration, an untrained colleague was able to use the framework to extract relevant attribution information, showing usability for information sharing.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: Anecdotal usability evidence is positive but limited (single demonstration). Systematic usability testing and metrics (time, error rates) are needed to substantiate the claim at scale.

evidence_harvesting.quote: The ultimate goal of the project is to create a framework suitable for the sharing of attribution data between technical specialists.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: Methodologically, the study sets out to build a shared attribution-data framework to enable exchange between technical specialists.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This objective drives design choices (library format, attribute tuples, confidence values). It implicitly assumes cross-team cooperation and compatible data semantics — a socio-technical challenge that requires governance and standards.

evidence_harvesting.quote: The framework must be robust enough to enable expansion as technologies develop, however accurate enough to be useful to analysts in todays attribution problem.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: Design requirement: the framework must be extensible for future technologies while remaining accurate and practical for analysts today.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This highlights a core trade-off (extensibility vs. precision) and motivates the chosen mathematical/confidence modelling. Implementers will need validation metrics and governance to balance extensibility with analytic reliability.

evidence_harvesting.quote: The model is not design for strategic analysis.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The authors explicitly state the model is not intended for strategic‑level attribution analysis.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This limitation confines the framework to tactical/operational use; it should not be used directly for national-level or political attribution without integration with higher-level models. Users must avoid over-extending conclusions beyond scope.

evidence_harvesting.quote: There is a concern that with too many libraries the framework would become too cumbersome and a great level of knowledge would be required in order to use it.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The thesis warns that proliferation of libraries could make the system cumbersome and require significant user expertise to operate.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This identifies an operational scalability and usability risk; it implies the need for library governance, discovery/search, and UX strategies (or role-based views) to keep the system practical for analysts.

evidence_harvesting.quote: A lot of time was wasted during the project developing libraries that ultimately were incompatible or out of date.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The project experienced significant time loss creating libraries that became incompatible or obsolete, revealing maintenance challenges.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This operational lesson signals a need for versioning, lifecycle management, and standards for library creation. It weakens reproducibility unless addressed by process improvements.

evidence_harvesting.quote: From the experimentation it has been found that the framework could be improved through the highlighting of new information as it is being populated.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: They recommend adding an interface feature to highlight newly added information during live population of the framework.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: A low-cost, actionable UX improvement that likely enhances analyst situational awareness in fast-time investigations. Should be implemented and validated with time-to-detection/user-satisfaction metrics.

evidence_harvesting.quote: Proposed libraries would include, but are not limited to; - HTML - Scripting languages - Social Media - IPV6 - Bluetooth
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The authors propose expanding the library set to include HTML, scripting languages, social media, IPv6 and Bluetooth libraries.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: This list mixes application-layer (HTML, social media) and protocol/physical-layer (IPv6, Bluetooth) targets; each has distinct collection, legal and feature-selection challenges that must be scoped separately.

evidence_harvesting.quote: Powershell, Python and Ruby should be prioritised due to their extensive use in cyber attacks.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: They recommend prioritising PowerShell, Python and Ruby libraries because these scripting languages are heavily used in cyber attacks.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: Prioritising these scripting languages aligns with operational threat patterns and should yield high impact for attribution. Implementation is feasible because these languages expose rich, author-specific artefacts (e.g., scripting idioms, module use).

evidence_harvesting.quote: An obvious library that is missing is for IP Version 6.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The authors identify IPv6 support as a missing library to be added in future work.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: IPv6 adoption is growing; omitting IPv6 limits future applicability. IPv6 carries different header fields and extension headers that could provide new attribution signals, so this is a high-priority gap.

evidence_harvesting.quote: adopt a widely recognised data exchange format such as STIX *Barnum (2012)*.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: They recommend adopting a standard threat‑intelligence exchange format (STIX) to improve interoperability and adoption.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: Integrating STIX would aid interoperability with other CTI tools but requires a careful mapping from the framework's attribute model to STIX structures. This is non-trivial and needs an explicit schema/mapping effort.

evidence_list.quote: An Actor, A, is an entity or person who is performing an action through cyber means.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The framework models an Actor (A) as an entity or person performing actions via cyber means.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This is a simple formalisation anchoring the actor-centric model; useful for mapping attributes to actors, but the model assumes attributes can be associated with actors which may be contested in noisy environments.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence_list.quote: There is currently no formalised system to enable the sharing of attribution data between multiple disciplines.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors assert there is no standardized system for multi-disciplinary sharing of attribution data.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This gap motivates the proposed framework; note the author acknowledges commercial/private solutions exist but not a formal open system—this claim merits external verification.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence_list.quote: A number of these technical solutions require a fundamental change to the way in which networking and the internet works.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Many proposed technical traceback/attribution solutions demand fundamental changes to internet architecture.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This highlights scalability and deployment barriers for several academic proposals; it supports the pragmatic focus on deployable, incremental solutions. It also raises policy and governance obstacles.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence_list.quote: This first experiment resulted in a 100% success rate with all candidates successfully identifying the intelligence gap.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Experiment 1 reported that all participants (100%) correctly identified intelligence gaps using the framework.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Strong usability signal for the gap-detection visualisation, but sample size and test design details are limited; results may not generalize beyond the experiment's participants and conditions.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence_list.quote: The tool was run over a sample of 18,000 (N) previously known malware samples.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors executed static analysis on a malware corpus of 18,000 samples to assess attribute prevalence.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Large-sample static analysis increases empirical weight of findings; however static-only analysis misses dynamic indicators and may under-detect network artifacts.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence_list.quote: The results of the static analysis found that there are a number of attributes that meet the requirements. These were: - IP Address - Domain - Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA) - E-Mail - BitCoin Address - Date of Compilation - Dropped Files - Packer - Entropy - Strings
evidence_list.paraphrase: Static analysis identified repeatable malware attributes useful for attribution: IP, domain, DGA, email, bitcoin address, compilation date, dropped files, packer, entropy, and strings.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This enumerated attribute set is empirically derived and can feed library development; several items (IP, domain, bitcoin) have strong linkage potential, others (strings, entropy) are noisy and require aggregation.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence_list.quote: The experiment verified the attributes selected from the original data set are the most prevalent for the use in attribution. The experiment however highlighted the requirement to not rely on an individual attribute in isolation, and it is the collection of attributes as a whole that create the fingerprint.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Experiments validated prevalent attribution attributes but emphasized that reliable fingerprints require combining multiple attributes rather than relying on any single indicator.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This synthesis is a key empirical insight: multi-attribute fusion yields better linkage than single markers. Caveat: verification used known malware families (proxy for same author) rather than independently proven authorship.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence_list.quote: It was shown to be suitable for multidisciplinary work through the inclusion of linguistic and RF libraries.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The framework was demonstrated to support multidisciplinary attribution by incorporating linguistic and radio-frequency libraries.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This supports extensibility claims and the core novelty (multidisciplinary data fusion). Testing scope was limited to selected libraries; broader interoperability remains to be proven.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence_list.quote: Proposed libraries would include, but are not limited to; - HTML - Scripting languages - Social Media - IPV6 - Bluetooth
evidence_list.paraphrase: Future work proposes additional libraries for HTML, scripting languages, social media, IPv6 and Bluetooth to broaden attribution coverage.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Author outlines clear extension roadmap that targets important application and physical-layer sources; implementation and maintenance overheads are non-trivial and would affect scalability.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 6 Conclusions & Future Works ... 130 + ## 7 Reference ... 134 + ### 1.1 Problem Statement

evidence_list.quote: For the purposes of cyber attribution, our focus is from that of cyber security.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The thesis limits the concept of 'cyber' for attribution work to a cyber-security perspective, i.e. attributes relevant to security analysts.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This statement narrows the project's scope to cyber‑security use cases, which clarifies which attributes will be prioritised. It excludes broader socio-technical interpretations of 'cyber' and will shape library/feature selection. Analysts should note this when mapping findings to other research questions outside security-focused attribution.

evidence_list.quote: for the purpose of this thesis it was decided that cyber was information based.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The thesis defines 'cyber' as information‑based, i.e. focused on digital information (data and metadata) for attribution purposes.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Explicitly framing 'cyber' as information-based steers attribute collection toward digital artefacts and metadata rather than non-digital context. This decision helps bound the framework but may omit non-digital signals that could be relevant in some attribution cases.

evidence_list.quote: Although this phrase was originally used as a slang term for the internet its official dictionary definition is ”a realm of electronic communication”.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The document adopts the dictionary meaning of 'cyber space' as 'a realm of electronic communication', covering any medium that transmits or stores digital information.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: A purposely broad, medium‑agnostic definition that permits inclusion of RF, wired, and other channels in attribution libraries. The breadth aids extensibility but may increase heterogeneity of attributes to manage.

evidence_list.quote: Cyber Security therefore relates to any action that is required to keep the information safe and available.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Cyber security is defined as actions taken to keep information safe and available (i.e., preservation of CIA properties) for attribution and defence.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Tying security to information availability/safety focuses attribution on evidence that affects confidentiality, integrity, and availability. The definition also explicitly allows physical attacks on equipment to be considered under 'cyber security'.

evidence_list.quote: Ultimately it is the search for characteristics which can be associated with an attack or an individual.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The thesis frames cyber attribution as the identification of characteristics that can be associated with an attack or an individual actor.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This operational definition justifies building attribute libraries and a taxonomy of features. It is intentionally broad — 'characteristics' must be disambiguated into concrete, testable attributes (which the thesis attempts via libraries).

evidence_list.quote: The ultimate goal of traceback attribution is to follow the communications back to the original source, usually in the form of an IP address.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Traceback attribution aims to trace communications back to their origin, typically identified as an IP address.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This sets expectations for what traceback can provide but the thesis elsewhere notes practical obstacles (spoofing, proxies, non-cooperative networks). The definition is network-centric and may understate challenges in attributing persons rather than devices.

evidence_list.quote: Full attribution is when a specific action can be assigned to an individual person.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Full attribution is defined as assigning a specific cyber action to a named individual, the level required for legal proceedings.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This distinguishes levels of attribution and highlights that 'full attribution' carries much higher evidentiary burdens than device- or traceback-level attribution. It signals the need for rigorous evidentiary standards for legal use.

evidence_list.quote: At the conclusion of the project there is a proposed framework for the use of analysts working on the attribution problem.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The project's principal output is a proposed analyst-oriented cyber attribution framework.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This is the central deliverable claimed by the thesis; subsequent text summarises validation experiments but further external validation and peer replication are needed to judge generalisability. The claim is descriptive of output rather than evaluative.

evidence_list.quote: It was shown to be suitable for multidisciplinary work through the inclusion of linguistic and RF libraries.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors report the framework is suitable for multidisciplinary collaboration by incorporating linguistic and radio‑frequency libraries.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Empirical support is limited to those two library domains; while encouraging, this result does not prove generalisability across other disciplines. Integration and semantic-mapping challenges between domains remain an implementation risk.

evidence_list.quote: This was an especially pleasing demonstration of the framework as an information sharing platform as a colleague without any prior training was able to use the framework to extract the relevant information.
evidence_list.paraphrase: In a live demonstration, an untrained colleague was able to use the framework to extract relevant attribution information, showing usability for information sharing.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Anecdotal usability evidence is positive but limited (single demonstration). Systematic usability testing and metrics (time, error rates) are needed to substantiate the claim at scale.

evidence_list.quote: The ultimate goal of the project is to create a framework suitable for the sharing of attribution data between technical specialists.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Methodologically, the study sets out to build a shared attribution-data framework to enable exchange between technical specialists.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This objective drives design choices (library format, attribute tuples, confidence values). It implicitly assumes cross-team cooperation and compatible data semantics — a socio-technical challenge that requires governance and standards.

evidence_list.quote: The framework must be robust enough to enable expansion as technologies develop, however accurate enough to be useful to analysts in todays attribution problem.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Design requirement: the framework must be extensible for future technologies while remaining accurate and practical for analysts today.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This highlights a core trade-off (extensibility vs. precision) and motivates the chosen mathematical/confidence modelling. Implementers will need validation metrics and governance to balance extensibility with analytic reliability.

evidence_list.quote: The model is not design for strategic analysis.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors explicitly state the model is not intended for strategic‑level attribution analysis.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This limitation confines the framework to tactical/operational use; it should not be used directly for national-level or political attribution without integration with higher-level models. Users must avoid over-extending conclusions beyond scope.

evidence_list.quote: There is a concern that with too many libraries the framework would become too cumbersome and a great level of knowledge would be required in order to use it.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The thesis warns that proliferation of libraries could make the system cumbersome and require significant user expertise to operate.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This identifies an operational scalability and usability risk; it implies the need for library governance, discovery/search, and UX strategies (or role-based views) to keep the system practical for analysts.

evidence_list.quote: A lot of time was wasted during the project developing libraries that ultimately were incompatible or out of date.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The project experienced significant time loss creating libraries that became incompatible or obsolete, revealing maintenance challenges.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This operational lesson signals a need for versioning, lifecycle management, and standards for library creation. It weakens reproducibility unless addressed by process improvements.

evidence_list.quote: From the experimentation it has been found that the framework could be improved through the highlighting of new information as it is being populated.
evidence_list.paraphrase: They recommend adding an interface feature to highlight newly added information during live population of the framework.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: A low-cost, actionable UX improvement that likely enhances analyst situational awareness in fast-time investigations. Should be implemented and validated with time-to-detection/user-satisfaction metrics.

evidence_list.quote: Proposed libraries would include, but are not limited to; - HTML - Scripting languages - Social Media - IPV6 - Bluetooth
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors propose expanding the library set to include HTML, scripting languages, social media, IPv6 and Bluetooth libraries.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This list mixes application-layer (HTML, social media) and protocol/physical-layer (IPv6, Bluetooth) targets; each has distinct collection, legal and feature-selection challenges that must be scoped separately.

evidence_list.quote: Powershell, Python and Ruby should be prioritised due to their extensive use in cyber attacks.
evidence_list.paraphrase: They recommend prioritising PowerShell, Python and Ruby libraries because these scripting languages are heavily used in cyber attacks.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Prioritising these scripting languages aligns with operational threat patterns and should yield high impact for attribution. Implementation is feasible because these languages expose rich, author-specific artefacts (e.g., scripting idioms, module use).

evidence_list.quote: An obvious library that is missing is for IP Version 6.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors identify IPv6 support as a missing library to be added in future work.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: IPv6 adoption is growing; omitting IPv6 limits future applicability. IPv6 carries different header fields and extension headers that could provide new attribution signals, so this is a high-priority gap.

evidence_list.quote: adopt a widely recognised data exchange format such as STIX *Barnum (2012)*.
evidence_list.paraphrase: They recommend adopting a standard threat‑intelligence exchange format (STIX) to improve interoperability and adoption.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Integrating STIX would aid interoperability with other CTI tools but requires a careful mapping from the framework's attribute model to STIX structures. This is non-trivial and needs an explicit schema/mapping effort.

metadata.title: Developing Political Response Framework to Cyber Hostilities
rq_lines: 0: What types of evidence are used?
1: What methods are used?
2: How are frameworks and models operationalized for cyber attribution?

section_open_coding.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: First, the adversary is usually difficult to locate. Cyberspace allows for a great deal of anonymity, and attacks can be routed through servers all over the world to mask their origin.
evidence.paraphrase: The text states that cyberspace anonymity and global routing make locating attackers difficult, directly creating an attribution challenge relevant to cyber attribution.
evidence.researcher_comment: This is a direct technical explanation of why attribution is hard and why evidentiary chains are weak. It underlines the need for non-technical corroboration (political/intelligence) when attributing. The passage does not discuss forensic mitigations or how often routing prevents attribution.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: Fourth, an aspect complicating cyber attacks and their legal evaluation is that cyber operations have often been conducted by non-state actors, whose status and affiliation are not always clear.
evidence.paraphrase: The author asserts that frequent use of non-state actors with unclear affiliations complicates legal evaluation and attribution of cyber operations, a central issue for cyber attribution.
evidence.researcher_comment: Identifies actor-identity ambiguity as both an evidentiary and legal barrier to attribution and prosecution. Useful for RQs on who must be attributed (state vs non-state). The passage does not specify methods to resolve affiliation ambiguity.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: Political incentive for states to use proxies can be summed up by the concept of "plausible deniability".
evidence.paraphrase: The chapter argues that states have incentives to employ proxies to retain plausible deniability, which systematically impedes reliable attribution (relevant to cyber attribution).
evidence.researcher_comment: Links political motives to operational behaviors that intentionally degrade attribution confidence; important for political-response analysis. The statement is schematic and not backed here by empirical examples in this quote.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: the report stated that the indication that cyber activity was launched or otherwise originated from the territory or the ICT infrastructure of a state may be insufficient in itself to attribute the activity to that state (United Nations 2016).
evidence.paraphrase: A UN expert report concluded that evidence of activity originating from a state's territory or ICT infrastructure alone may be insufficient to attribute responsibility to that state, directly addressing evidentiary limits for attribution.
evidence.researcher_comment: This is authoritative confirmation (UN) that technical origin evidence is often legally insufficient for attribution, which matters for rules of engagement and international responses. The quote does not specify what additional evidence would meet attribution standards.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: States retain the inherent right to self-defense under Article 51 of the UN Charter when faced with an imminent threat.
evidence.paraphrase: The author notes that states retain the Article 51 right of self-defense when faced with imminent threats, which provides a legal basis for responding to cyber threats contingent on attribution and threat assessment.
evidence.researcher_comment: Places state response options within established UN legal doctrine, indicating a potential legal route for responses to cyber incidents. The passage, however, acknowledges elsewhere that attribution and impact thresholds complicate invoking Article 51 in practice.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: The challenge of attribution and the understanding of the extent to which a cyber attack has caused (or has the potential to cause) damage make things more complicated in reality.
evidence.paraphrase: The text states that attribution difficulties combined with uncertainty about an attack's causal damage complicate political and legal responses to cyber incidents, a core issue for cyber attribution.
evidence.researcher_comment: Highlights that attribution and impact assessment are joint constraints on lawful and proportionate responses; this is essential for RQs on thresholds for action. The passage does not operationalize damage metrics.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: The legal debate on what constitutes an 'armed attack in cyberspace' has only just begun.
evidence.paraphrase: The author observes that legal scholarship and practice are at an early stage in defining when cyber operations qualify as 'armed attacks', directly bearing on attribution-linked thresholds for force.
evidence.researcher_comment: Notes unresolved legal thresholds that determine when a state may lawfully respond with force—critical for RQs about legal criteria. The passage is high-level and does not enumerate candidate tests or state practice.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: It is conceivable that a harmful cyber hostility that is attributable to a state amounts to a violation of Article 2 (4) of the UN Charter, given its character and effects.
evidence.paraphrase: The author suggests that a state-attributable harmful cyber act could, depending on its nature and effects, violate Article 2(4) of the UN Charter, linking attribution to possible breaches of the prohibition on force.
evidence.researcher_comment: Connects successful attribution to significant legal consequences (use-of-force prohibition), which is important for RQs about why attribution matters politically and legally. The phrasing is conditional and does not specify evaluative criteria.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: One of the most common ones is based on the Tallinn Manual, which offers the definition of a 'cyber attack' as 'a cyber operation, whether offensive or defensive, that is reasonably expected to cause injury or death to persons or damage or destruction to objects' (Tallinn Manual 2013).
evidence.paraphrase: The Tallinn Manual's definition frames 'cyber attack' narrowly around operations reasonably expected to cause physical injury, death, or destruction, which sets a high threshold relevant to attribution and response policy.
evidence.researcher_comment: Provides a canonical, 'hard' legal definition that emphasizes physical effects and thus narrows what incidents trigger forceful responses. This matters for RQs on how definitional choices affect attribution thresholds and policy options.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: This definition is pretty "hard,' requiring a severe impact of the cyber attack and strongly tied to the physical impact.
evidence.paraphrase: The author characterizes the Tallinn-style definition as 'hard' because it requires severe, typically physical, impact before labeling an operation a cyber attack, which narrows attribution triggers.
evidence.researcher_comment: Author's analysis highlights trade-offs: hard definitions limit false positives but exclude non-kinetic harms that may nonetheless be politically significant. The quote critiques the linkage to physical impact but does not propose an alternative metric here.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: A cyber attack, as a concept, must be understood widely in the political context: A cyber attack consists of any deliberate hostile action taken in cyberspace for a political, economic, or national security purpose.
evidence.paraphrase: The author proposes a broad, politically rooted definition: a cyber attack is any deliberate hostile cyberspace action undertaken for political, economic, or security ends, which would expand attribution scope.
evidence.researcher_comment: This normative framing contrasts with 'hard' legal thresholds and would widen the range of incidents treated as attacks for attribution and response purposes. It is prescriptive and signals the author's preferred scope for political decision-making.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: In December 2015, we witnessed the first confirmed cyber attack to take down a power grid, which affected approximately 225,000 civilians in Ukraine.
evidence.paraphrase: The chapter cites the December 2015 Ukraine power-grid incident—affecting about 225,000 civilians—as the first confirmed cyber attack that produced direct physical infrastructure failure, relevant to attribution/impact debates.
evidence.researcher_comment: Empirical example showing that cyber operations can cause physical harm meeting 'hard' definitions and thus enabling stronger legal/political responses. The quote does not discuss attribution for this incident in detail.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: The highest level, the level five (defined as an "emergency level"), will be used in a situation in which cyber attacks cause physical consequences.
evidence.paraphrase: The author notes that U.S. PPD-41 classifies incidents up to a 'level five' emergency to be invoked when cyber attacks cause physical consequences, linking physical impact to escalation policy.
evidence.researcher_comment: Demonstrates an operational classification that conditions maximal national response on physical consequences; useful for RQs on state-level thresholds and procedures. The quote does not address how attribution is integrated into declaring level five.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: One important recommendation was that a state should not conduct or knowingly support ICT activity that intentionally damages or otherwise impairs the use and operation of critical infrastructure.
evidence.paraphrase: The UN expert group's recommendation states that states should not conduct or knowingly support ICT activities that intentionally damage or impair critical infrastructure, tying state responsibility to conduct and support.
evidence.researcher_comment: A normative state obligation that bears on attribution because it assigns responsibility to states to prevent misuse of their ICT resources. The passage does not outline enforcement or attribution standards to hold states accountable.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: Even if the report emphasized that "making cyberspace stable and secure can be achieved only through international cooperation" and required states to take appropriate measures to protect their critical infrastructure, it did not give any guidance as to how to respond specifically to state-sponsored cyber attacks.
evidence.paraphrase: Although the UN report called for international cooperation and protective measures, it provided no concrete guidance on responding to state-sponsored cyber attacks, leaving a normative gap relevant to attribution and response frameworks.
evidence.researcher_comment: Points out a key limitation in international norms: exhortations for cooperation exist but actionable response guidance (and attribution thresholds) are absent. This gap is critical for RQs about the maturity of global attribution and response norms.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: Hybrid warfare increases "the fog of war', and cyber activities are well suited in this context for five reasons.
evidence.paraphrase: The author argues that hybrid warfare amplifies uncertainty (the 'fog of war') and that cyber operations are especially suitable for exploiting that uncertainty, which complicates attribution.
evidence.researcher_comment: Frames cyber operations as instruments of hybrid warfare that intentionally exploit ambiguity, reinforcing earlier claims about attribution difficulty. The quote introduces the concept; the five reasons are listed elsewhere in the text.
evidence.section_key: __preamble__ + ## The Importance of Politics in Cyber Affairs

evidence.quote: At the moment, international law is unable to cope with cyberspace-related hostilities.
evidence.paraphrase: This sentence states that current international law cannot adequately address hostilities in cyberspace, which is relevant to RQs about legal frameworks for cyber attribution and state response.
evidence.researcher_comment: Flags a legal-framework gap that shapes attribution and response options; the claim is asserted without empirical support here and needs specification of which legal regimes are implicated. Useful for RQs on normative/ legal constraints.

evidence.quote: The shared (legal) norms of cyberspace are still missing.
evidence.paraphrase: The author asserts that shared legal norms governing cyberspace have not yet been established, relevant to RQs on normative development in cyber attribution.
evidence.researcher_comment: Concise statement of normative vacuum; useful for framing research on international norm emergence. Lacks detail on which actors or proposals have failed or are absent.

evidence.quote: Attributing cyber attacks to their sponsor (which state or non-state actor is behind the particular attack) remains a significant challenge, as it requires effective measures with the ability to identify perpetrators behind the attacks.
evidence.paraphrase: Attributing a cyber attack to its sponsor remains a significant challenge because it requires effective measures to identify perpetrators, bearing directly on RQs about attribution feasibility.
evidence.researcher_comment: Direct statement of attribution difficulty; frames the problem as requiring technical/operational capabilities. Does not specify what 'effective measures' would be sufficient—useful prompt for operationalizing capability metrics.

evidence.quote: Cyberspace allows for a great deal of anonymity, and attacks can be routed through servers all over the world to mask their origin.
evidence.paraphrase: Anonymity and global routing in cyberspace enable attackers to mask their origin, explaining a mechanism that complicates attribution.
evidence.researcher_comment: Provides a concrete technical mechanism (routing/anonymity) that produces attribution uncertainty; useful for RQs on forensic limits and tracing techniques. Does not discuss mitigations (e.g., traffic correlation).

evidence.quote: Misattributing a cyber hostility could cause a response directed to the wrong target.
evidence.paraphrase: A mistaken attribution can lead states to direct responses at incorrect targets, relevant to RQs about escalation risk from attribution errors.
evidence.researcher_comment: Highlights the high-stakes consequence of attribution errors for policy responses; implies the need for confidence thresholds and checks. The excerpt does not provide empirical incidence data.

evidence.quote: For instance, if the level of attribution is low, decision-makers will be limited in their choice of response even if the severity of the attack is high.
evidence.paraphrase: Low confidence in attribution constrains policymakers' available response options even when an attack is severe, which is relevant to RQs about confidence thresholds and proportionality.
evidence.researcher_comment: Connects attribution confidence directly to feasible policy responses; useful for operationalizing 'confidence' in decision rules. Assumes risk aversion—political pressures may sometimes override this constraint.

evidence.quote: The ability to attribute an attack to a specific source is important for maintaining credibility and ensuring legitimacy at home and abroad.
evidence.paraphrase: Attribution capability is necessary to preserve domestic and international credibility and legitimacy, relevant to RQs on political effects of attribution.
evidence.researcher_comment: Links attribution to reputational and legitimacy costs/benefits; suggests that attribution decisions are as much about signaling as fact-finding. Does not operationalize 'credibility'.

evidence.quote: The challenge is that the sufficient proof of the attribution may be gathered via “secret intelligence data sources” or obtained from “friendly nations,” and the state does not want to reveal these intelligence sources publicly.
evidence.paraphrase: Sufficient attribution evidence may rely on secret intelligence or allied sources that states are unwilling to disclose publicly, complicating transparent attribution and its study.
evidence.researcher_comment: Identifies an evidentiary trade-off: secrecy versus public legitimacy. Highly relevant to RQs on evidentiary standards and public justification; suggests research into partial-disclosure tactics.

evidence.quote: Releasing at least some proof of attribution is necessary, if the state wants to build international legitimacy for whatever retaliatory actions it takes.
evidence.paraphrase: Publishing at least partial evidence is necessary for a state to build international legitimacy for retaliatory actions, relevant to RQs on transparency and legitimacy in attribution.
evidence.researcher_comment: Normative recommendation tying evidence disclosure to legitimacy. Useful for RQs on how much and what type of disclosure constrains adversaries or persuades allies; lacks empirical threshold guidance.

evidence.quote: Attribution involves many aspects, including technical, legal, and political.
evidence.paraphrase: Attribution is a multidimensional process encompassing technical, legal, and political components, relevant to RQs on multidisciplinary attribution processes.
evidence.researcher_comment: High-level definition that signals the need for interdisciplinary methods in RQs; does not describe how these dimensions interact or which dominates in practice.

evidence.quote: Attribution is an exercise of minimizing uncertainty on three levels: tactically, attribution is an art as well as a science; operationally, attribution is a nuanced process instead of a black-and-white problem; and strategically, attribution is a function of what is at stake politically.
evidence.paraphrase: Attribution reduces uncertainty at tactical, operational, and strategic levels—tactically art/science, operationally nuanced, and strategically politically conditioned—relevant to RQs seeking conceptual frameworks.
evidence.researcher_comment: Provides an explicit three-level framework useful for coding and structuring RQs (tactical/operational/strategic). Offers a conceptual lens for differentiating technical from political attribution questions.

evidence.quote: Successful attribution requires a range of skills at all levels, careful management, time, leadership, stress-testing, prudent communication, and recognizing limitations and challenges.
evidence.paraphrase: Accurate attribution requires diverse skills, organizational management, time, leadership, stress-testing, careful communication, and acknowledgement of limits, relevant to RQs on capability requirements.
evidence.researcher_comment: Enumerates human and institutional capacities needed for attribution, pointing to variables to measure in empirical studies. Does not provide metrics or prioritization among listed skills.

evidence.quote: Even if attribution capabilities are increasing due to the great interest of security experts in all three levels, the final conclusion of attribution in order to respond is always a political decision.
evidence.paraphrase: Despite improving capabilities, the decision to attribute for the purpose of response is ultimately political, which matters for RQs about decision-making processes.
evidence.researcher_comment: Key claim: technical evidence alone does not determine policy action; political incentives and audiences matter. Suggests RQs should incorporate political-institutional variables alongside technical indicators.

evidence.quote: It can take weeks, if not months or years, for computer forensic experts to accurately and conclusively ascertain the extent of the damage done to the target organization's computer networks.
evidence.paraphrase: Forensic assessment of cyber damage can require weeks to years to reach accurate, conclusive results, relevant to RQs on temporal constraints in attribution and response.
evidence.researcher_comment: Quantifies a significant temporal lag that constrains prompt attribution and response; this tension is central to RQs comparing forensic rigor with political urgency.

evidence.quote: The challenge in calculating proportionality in the cyber context resides in the speed and covert nature of cyber attacks: it is difficult to establish their magnitude and consequences.
evidence.paraphrase: Calculating proportionality is hampered by cyber attacks' speed and covert character, which makes it difficult to establish magnitude and consequences, relevant to RQs on proportionality assessments.
evidence.researcher_comment: Directly links attribution/forensics problems to international-law proportionality assessments; important for RQs on legal thresholds and response legitimacy. Lacks operational measures for 'magnitude'.

evidence.quote: It is said that every nation-state can respond using at least four instruments: diplomatic, informational, military, and economic.
evidence.paraphrase: States can respond to cyber hostilities using at least four instruments—diplomatic, informational, military, and economic—which is relevant to RQs on repertoire of state responses.
evidence.researcher_comment: Provides a simple taxonomy of state levers for response useful for comparative coding; does not discuss constraints or effectiveness of each instrument.

evidence.quote: Responses to cyber attacks may be delivered overtly or covertly.
evidence.paraphrase: Responses to cyber attacks can be overt or covert, a distinction relevant to RQs on signaling, attribution, and escalation dynamics.
evidence.researcher_comment: Important descriptive distinction affecting signaling and deterrence; prompts RQs on when states opt for covert versus overt measures and how that choice affects attribution credibility.

evidence.quote: If cyber methods are used, the latter can be difficult to develop quickly unless the government already has a prepared capability against a specific target, likely involving prior cyber espionage producing an unparalleled understanding of the target's vulnerabilities.
evidence.paraphrase: Covert cyber countermeasures are hard to create quickly and generally require pre-existing capabilities and prior espionage to exploit target vulnerabilities, relevant to RQs on preparedness.
evidence.researcher_comment: Highlights lead-times and preparatory requirements for effective cyber responses; implies that ad-hoc retaliation is often infeasible. Raises ethical/legal flags about prior espionage.

evidence.quote: States may also choose to outsource their responses to proxy hacker groups. By doing so, they may limit their control over the response, which may lead into escalatory activity.
evidence.paraphrase: Outsourcing responses to proxy hacker groups reduces state control and can provoke escalation, relevant to RQs on deniability, attribution, and escalation risk.
evidence.researcher_comment: Identifies outsourcing as a mechanism that increases attribution ambiguity and escalation risk; useful for RQs on state use of proxies and unintended consequences. Does not provide frequency or case data.

evidence.quote: The political pressure to respond especially increases when (1) the impacts of the cyber attack are acknowledged in public and (2) the official accusation of the attacker has been announced.
evidence.paraphrase: Political pressure to respond intensifies when attack impacts are publicized and an attacker is officially accused, which is relevant to RQs on timing and political constraints in attribution-driven responses.
evidence.researcher_comment: Specifies two public triggers that raise urgency and can shorten deliberation time; relevant for modeling temporal dynamics and political accountability in attribution decisions.

evidence.quote: understanding the level of attribution and the severity of the attack to evaluating proportional response
evidence.paraphrase: Policymakers must assess attribution certainty, attack severity, and proportional response when deciding how to react to cyber hostilities.
evidence.researcher_comment: Identifies core decision variables for a response framework; useful for mapping RQ components (attribution, severity, proportionality). Does not operationalize how to measure attribution or severity, limiting direct comparability across cases.

evidence.quote: Passivity in the face of cyber attacks will probably encourage opponents to engage in more aggression.
evidence.paraphrase: Passive responses to cyber attacks are likely to embolden adversaries and increase aggression.
evidence.researcher_comment: Provides a forward-looking rationale for proactive responses and deterrence measures; the modal term 'probably' signals limited evidentiary backing in this excerpt.

evidence.quote: Developing a framework within which to respond to cyber attacks allows policymakers to quickly consider solutions and counter with options previously analyzed for merit and possible consequences.
evidence.paraphrase: A pre-established response framework lets policymakers rapidly evaluate and deploy pre-assessed countermeasures during cyber incidents.
evidence.researcher_comment: Advocates pre-crisis planning to speed decision-making; supports institutionalizing options analysis but provides no procedural template or evaluation metrics.

evidence.quote: Identifying an appropriate response in advance could prevent the state from making mistakes that could unintentionally jeopardize political, economic, intelligence, and military interests.
evidence.paraphrase: Pre-defining responses helps states avoid inadvertent actions that would harm political, economic, intelligence, or military interests.
evidence.researcher_comment: Frames advance planning as harm-preventing across multiple national instruments; it assumes accurate scenario anticipation and does not address trade-offs among interests.

evidence.quote: According to the framework, the more severe the cyber attack is, the stronger the response needs to be.
evidence.paraphrase: The framework ties response intensity to attack severity, prescribing stronger responses for more severe cyber incidents.
evidence.researcher_comment: States a proportionality principle clearly; the passage does not specify how 'severity' is measured or how proportionality is operationalized in practice.

evidence.quote: The framework illustrates the impacts and severity of a cyber attack, with website defacement at one end of the scale and loss of life at the opposite end.
evidence.paraphrase: The framework presents an impact scale from minor incidents like website defacement to extreme outcomes such as loss of life.
evidence.researcher_comment: Provides illustrative endpoints for an impact taxonomy; useful for classifying incidents but simplistic—intermediate harms and contextual factors are not enumerated or weighted.

evidence.quote: Across the response spectrum, there will be inherent political and legal risks associated with each decision, and risks increase as the level of the response increases.
evidence.paraphrase: All response options carry political and legal risks, and those risks escalate with stronger responses.
evidence.researcher_comment: Highlights escalation trade-offs and legal exposure as central constraints on state action; does not specify which legal frameworks or thresholds are implicated.

evidence.quote: policymakers should also clearly understand the costs associated with each response.
evidence.paraphrase: Policymakers must explicitly assess the costs tied to each potential response option.
evidence.researcher_comment: Calls for cost-awareness as an input into the decision framework; the text does not provide a cost-assessment methodology or metrics.

evidence.quote: Assessing options will require input from relevant government agencies, as well as private sector companies, whose operations and businesses could be affected by the response.
evidence.paraphrase: Evaluating response choices requires interagency coordination and consultation with private-sector entities potentially affected by those responses.
evidence.researcher_comment: Emphasizes whole-of-government and public–private inputs; important for RQs on implementation but lacks detail on coordination mechanisms, authority, or timelines.

evidence.quote: On the one hand, redlines invite adversaries to act below the line, thinking that they have immunity or low political risk in carrying out their cyber operations.
evidence.paraphrase: Public redlines can encourage adversaries to operate below declared thresholds, assuming minimal political consequences.
evidence.researcher_comment: Explains a strategic downside of explicit thresholds; supports caution about public signaling but offers no empirical calibration of 'below the line' behavior.

evidence.quote: Redlines can also push states into a corner so that they have to respond when the line is crossed in order to preserve their credibility.
evidence.paraphrase: Defined redlines risk forcing states to retaliate when breached to maintain credibility.
evidence.researcher_comment: Identifies credibility costs and potential entrapment from fixed thresholds; relevant for RQs on signaling and escalation management.

evidence.quote: A certain degree of imprecision may be the best solution politically: to announce that there will be a response, but that details will not be revealed beforehand.
evidence.paraphrase: Strategic political ambiguity—committing to respond while withholding specifics—may be the optimal approach.
evidence.researcher_comment: Advocates strategic ambiguity to preserve deterrence without constraining future options; the recommendation is normative and not empirically validated here.

evidence.quote: Ultimately, the decision as to whether a cyber attack is an act of war or something else is a political one, particularly in cases that fall into the gray area between annoyance and actions that attempt to end the existence of a state.
evidence.paraphrase: Whether a cyber incident counts as an act of war is ultimately a political judgment, especially for ambiguous cases.
evidence.researcher_comment: Places incident classification in the political domain rather than as purely legal/technical determination; useful for RQs on attribution-to-response linkages and political thresholds.

evidence.quote: Protocols for responding to cyber hostilities are unclear, which should be understood as a lack of power in cyberspace.
evidence.paraphrase: Ambiguous response protocols reflect a deficit of decisive power or control in cyberspace.
evidence.researcher_comment: Frames procedural ambiguity as symptomatic of limited cyber power; causal claim that would require cross-case evidence to substantiate fully.

evidence.quote: Given the likely pressure governments will feel to respond to cyber attacks, policymakers need to develop a response framework of their own before disruptive or destructive cyber hostilities occur.
evidence.paraphrase: Because governments will face pressure to act after cyber attacks, they should prepare national response frameworks in advance.
evidence.researcher_comment: Reiterates the need for pre-existing national frameworks to avoid reactive errors under pressure; does not provide sequencing or resourcing guidance.

evidence.quote: The need for establishing boundaries in cyberpolitics is critical, as without them, nations leave their borders and critical systems open to cyber attacks from foreign actors with impunity.
evidence.paraphrase: Establishing clear boundaries in cyberpolitics is essential to prevent foreign actors from attacking national systems with impunity.
evidence.researcher_comment: Frames boundary-setting as necessary for defense and deterrence; does not specify who sets boundaries or how compliance would be enforced internationally.

evidence.quote: There are plenty of different diplomatic, informational, military, and economic ways to respond, and each state must consider which ways are suitable to them in each situation.
evidence.paraphrase: States can respond with diplomatic, informational, military, or economic measures and should select instruments appropriate to their context.
evidence.researcher_comment: Enumerates multi-domain response options and emphasizes contextual tailoring; useful to map instrument sets but lacks decision criteria for selection.

evidence.quote: One key issue is to consider either physical or cyber response—or both of them together.
evidence.paraphrase: Decision-makers must weigh physical responses, cyber responses, or combined options when reacting to cyber hostilities.
evidence.researcher_comment: Highlights integration of kinetic and cyber options and the need to consider combined effects; does not address legal or escalation implications of mixing domains.

evidence.quote: There is also a possibility for covert response: not to make effects public and no claim of responsibility for the actions.
evidence.paraphrase: States may choose covert responses that conceal effects and avoid claiming responsibility.
evidence.researcher_comment: Notes deniable/covert options and their practical appeal; raises attribution and normative accountability questions not resolved here.

evidence.quote: In practice, responses and reactions to cyber attacks will probably involve high levels of secrecy.
evidence.paraphrase: Actual responses to cyber attacks are likely to be conducted with significant secrecy.
evidence.researcher_comment: Signals operational secrecy constraints and transparency trade-offs; important for RQs on evidence disclosure and public attribution but lacking empirical support in the excerpt.

evidence.quote: Applegate S (2013) The dawn of kinetic cyber. In: Podins K, Stinissen J, Maybaum M (eds) 5th international conference on cyber conflict. NATO CCD COE Publications, Tallinn ACSC (2016) Threat report 2016. https://www.acsc.gov.au/publications/ACSC_Threat_Report_2016.pdf. Accessed 25 Oct 2016 Babcock C (2015) Preparing fo...
evidence.paraphrase: Section indicates framework_usage, policy_implication in relation to the overarching theme.
evidence.researcher_comment: Section-level open coding signal extracted from available text.

evidence.quote: Applegate S (2013) The dawn of kinetic cyber. In: Podins K, Stinissen J, Maybaum M (eds) 5th international conference on cyber conflict. NATO CCD COE Publications, Tallinn ACSC (2016) Threat report 2016. https://www.acsc.gov.au/publications/ACSC_Threat_Report_2016.pdf. Accessed 25 Oct 2016 Babcock C (2015) Preparing fo...
evidence.paraphrase: Section indicates framework_usage, policy_implication in relation to the overarching theme.
evidence.researcher_comment: Section-level open coding signal extracted from available text.

evidence.quote: Applegate S (2013) The dawn of kinetic cyber. In: Podins K, Stinissen J, Maybaum M (eds) 5th international conference on cyber conflict. NATO CCD COE Publications, Tallinn ACSC (2016) Threat report 2016. https://www.acsc.gov.au/publications/ACSC_Threat_Report_2016.pdf. Accessed 25 Oct 2016 Babcock C (2015) Preparing fo...
evidence.paraphrase: Section indicates framework_usage, policy_implication in relation to the overarching theme.
evidence.researcher_comment: Section-level open coding signal extracted from available text.

evidence_harvesting.quote: States retain the inherent right to self-defense under Article 51 of the UN Charter when faced with an imminent threat.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: This states that under Article 51 states have a right of self-defense when facing an imminent threat, relevant to RQs about legal bases for state responses to cyber incidents.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: Identifies the international legal basis commonly invoked for state responses to cyber incidents; does not specify how 'imminent threat' is operationalized in cyber contexts. Useful for legal-RQ synthesis but requires caution when applied to non-kinetic incidents.

evidence_harvesting.quote: The right to self-defense, including the use of force, would apply if a cyber attack reached the level of an “armed attack”.
evidence_harvesting.paraphrase: The author asserts that use-of-force self-defense may apply if a cyber incident qualifies as an 'armed attack', relevant to RQs on thresholds for forceful responses to cyber operations.
evidence_harvesting.researcher_comment: Links cyber incidents to traditional use-of-force doctrine and highlights the legal threshold concept; the excerpt does not operationalize what constitutes an 'armed attack' in cyberspace.

evidence_harvesting.quote: The legal debate on what constitutes an “armed attack in cyberspace” has only just begun.
